journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Collision detection system design using a multi-layer laser scanner for collision mitigation

contrib-group.aff: Department of Automotive Engineering, Hanyang University, Seongdong-gu, Seoul, Republic of Korea

author-notes.corresp: Kunsoo Huh, Department of Automotive Engineering, Hanyang University, 17 Haengdang-dong, Seongdong-gu, Seoul 133-791, Republic of Korea. Email: khuh2@hanyang.ac.kr

abstract.p: Collision detection plays a key role in collision mitigation systems. The malfunction of a collision mitigation system can result in a dangerous or unexpected situation for the driver and passengers. In order to prevent this situation, reliable collision detection algorithms are essential in terms of the collision time, the overlap and the collision decision. This study focuses on the reliable determination of the time to collision and the frontal overlap between the ego vehicle and the objects. The path prediction method using information on the ego vehicle is proposed to improve the accuracies of the time to collision and the frontal overlap calculations. The proposed algorithm is developed on the basis of a multi-layer laser scanner. The procedure of collision detection includes three steps. The first step is to select a high-risk object among multiple objects, the second step is to judge the time to collision and the frontal overlap to the high-risk object and, finally, the third step is to decide whether a crash is imminent or not. The performance of the proposed detection algorithm is validated in simulations and experiments.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Most car manufacturers are currently developing active safety systems to improve the safety of the driver and passengers. Active safety systems such as adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning systems, collision mitigation systems and collision avoidance systems are believed to be potentially effective in mitigating or preventing collisions. Recent technology developments in the field of active safety systems have made fast progress owing to safety regulations. In particular, research studies on collision mitigation systems are very active, e.g. the City Safety system introduced by Volvo.1 If the driver is about to drive into the vehicle in front and does not react in time, the car brakes itself. Mercedes–Benz has introduced the concept of the brake bag which is mounted in front on the vehicle crossbar to generate extra frictional force between the bag and roadway.2 For collision mitigation systems, the accuracy of the time to collision (TTC) and the frontal overlap (FO) calculations is very important. The FO is needed to judge whether the ego vehicle collides with an object or not, where the ego vehicle refers to a host vehicle equipped with collision mitigation systems. For example, if the driver steers before a crash, the ego vehicle may head off the collision. Unintended injuries or damage have been caused by an incorrect decision about collision in various driving situations.3

Collision information for active safety systems has been studied by many researchers. Tu and Kiang4 proposed an estimation approach of the radial distance, velocity, and acceleration using an extended Kalman filter and a two-stage linear Kalman filter. The collision avoidance system introduced by Volvo in 2002 suggested decision making based on the probability density function for the relative position from the ego vehicle to the most dangerous object.5 Researchers from Volvo, Ford and The University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI)6 developed a safety impact methodology which applies modelling, simulation and statistical analysis and fuses a wide variety of data from crash, naturalistic driving, driving simulator, test track and highway sources. Kusano and Gabler7 determined an upper bound for the effectiveness of automated pre-crash braking in reducing the number of injured drivers in the striking vehicle of rear-end collisions if every vehicle in the US fleet were equipped with a functioning pre-collision system.

Development of collision avoidance systems led to further research on how to perceive surroundings and how to integrate sensor signals. For instance, Moritz8 presented pre-crash sensing technology that uses a short-range radar sensor platform and integrates all possible functions based on sensor information from the surroundings. Skutek et al.9 proposed a methodology for data fusion of laser scanner and short-range radars to perceive surrounding information. This algorithm is based on a virtual grid in front of the vehicle into which the sensor readings are mapped. Pietzsch et al.10 also conducted experiments on a vehicle safety application based on data gathered by a laser scanner and two short-range radars.

Collision detection refers to a computational problem of predicting the collision between ego vehicle and objects. It calculates the TTC and the FO. Because accurate TTC and FO information is very important for collision mitigation systems, high-technology sensors are utilized such as radar, camera vision and ultrasonic sensors. Such systems give a warning alarm for possible crashes and may activate the brake pedal or the steering wheel to avoid crashes.11–13 Other scanning sensors such as a multi-layer laser scanner can also be used to detect the surroundings in the form of objects with relevant properties. However, a multi-layer laser scanner has a relatively low scanning frequency, namely 10–20 Hz, and the scanned data may not be sufficient to obtain accurate TTC and FO data.

In this study, a path prediction method using information on the ego vehicle is proposed to improve the accuracies of the TTC and the FO. The relative positions and orientations between the ego vehicle and objects are predicted on the basis of a laser scanner output and the ego vehicle’s motion data. The TTC and the FO calculation algorithms are modified to reflect the predicted path. The path prediction method is presented in the second section. The collision detection algorithm is explained in the third section. In the fourth section, the performance of this approach is evaluated through several simulation scenarios and experiments.

sec.title: Path prediction method
sec.p: Range sensors such as laser scanners can provide the relative distances and velocities between the ego vehicle and objects. However, with the limited sensor technology it is difficult to calculate the TTCs and FOs accurately using information on only the relative velocities and distances. It is believed that the accuracy of the TTC and the FO can be improved by considering the predicted path of the ego vehicle. The path prediction method has been extensively studied by researchers in the field of a missile’s aiming point.14 They calculated the aiming point of a missile assuming that the missile is moving at a constant acceleration in the longitudinal direction and the lateral direction respectively. The same methodology can be applied to the path prediction problem of a vehicle. For example, Brännström et al.15 developed a kinetic-model-based threat assessment for avoiding arbitrary vehicle collisions.

This study proposes a kinematic-model-based path prediction method using the sensor data together with the motion data of the ego vehicle. The sensor data from the multilayer laser scanner consists of the object box and the object contour points in the scanning range. The object box represents filtered object information during tracking and it is described in a rectangle, as shown in Figure 1. The relative longitudinal and lateral velocities are provided for object boxes by a tracking algorithm. The object contour points describe the outline of the object scanned from the sensor and they are illustrated as a series of dots in Figure 1. The locations of the object contour points are more accurate than the object box data, because the object box is generated on the basis of the scanned contour points which may not describe the whole object shape. The longitudinal and lateral accelerations and the yaw rate of the ego vehicle are obtained from the vehicle’s motion data. The proposed path prediction method can calculate the path of the object contour points by considering the relative motions. Figure 1 shows the algorithm concept of the path prediction of the object contour points.

caption.p: The proposed algorithm concept.

sec.p: The predicted object motion is represented by translational and rotational motions. The translational motion is affected by the predicted velocity, and the rotational motion is affected by yaw angle. The relative velocity can be predicted on the basis of the longitudinal and lateral accelerations and the yaw rate of the ego vehicle according to

sec.title: Collision detection
sec.p: Figure 2 shows the overall structure of the collision detection system. Collision detection consists of three steps. The first step is to select the high-risk object among multiple objects. The second step is to calculate the TTC and the FO using the predicted object information obtained from the path prediction method introduced from the second section. The third step is to determine the timing to activate the actuator of the collision mitigation system.

caption.p: The overall structure of collision detection.
FO: frontal overlap; TTC: time to collision.

sec.title: High-risk object selection
sec.p: The high-risk object is selected on the basis of the conventional TTC and the direction of the relative velocity vector from the ego vehicle to the objects.16 The relative velocity vector and the conventional TTC are expressed as
and
respectively where the subscript ID represents the identification number of an object.
The objects whose directions of relative velocity are not towards the ego vehicle are removed from the scanned multiple objects. The object with the minimum TTCID is selected as the high-risk object.

sec.title: Calculations of the frontal overlap and the time to collision
sec.p: Calculations of the FO and the TTC use the proposed path prediction method introduced in the second section. The basic process is shown in Figure 1. The path of the contour points on the high-risk object can be predicted using the path prediction method until the object is about to collide with the ego vehicle. The predicted path is calculated with an interval of 80 ms and the predicted contour points in Figure 1 show the 320 ms prediction results. The conventional TTC and FO are based only on the laser scanner data without considering the path prediction, while the present authors’ proposed TTC and FO are based on the predicted contour points until the collision time.

sec.title: Frontal overlap
sec.p: The FO is needed to judge whether the ego vehicle collides with an object or not. For example, if the driver steers before a crash, the ego vehicle may head off the collision. In this situation, the predicted FO becomes zero even though the collision is expected from a TTC value. The FO between the ego vehicle and the predicted object is illustrated in Figure 3. lp_obj_ID and lp_ego are the lengths of the object (numbered as the object’s ID) and the ego vehicle respectively projected on to the plane orthogonal to the predicted relative velocity. drel is the length of the region of interest and is proportional to the relative velocity according to

caption.p: The FO calculation.

sec.p: Here timpact is the design parameter for the region of interest, and its size depends on the system requirement. In other words, the contour points beyond the rectangle defined by lp_ego and drel do not make contact with the ego vehicle when the collision occurs. Equation (10) is used to remove the contour points which do not overlap with the ego vehicle at the collision even though these points are positioned on the direction of the vehicle ahead. Only the contour points within the rectangle defined by lp_ego_i and drel are considered in calculating the FO. Then, the FO can be calculated as

The distance between the front of the vehicle and the predicted contour point can be calculated using the location of the predicted object contour point and the frontal geometry of the ego vehicle. Again, only the contour points within the rectangle defined by lp_ego and drel are considered. The TTC can be calculated using the predicted relative velocity and di according to
where
di = distance from the frontal outline of the ego vehicle to the predicted contour point at time tp
TTCpre_i = TTC from the ego vehicle to the predicted contour point
TTCi = TTC from the ego vehicle to the current contour point
TTCi is obtained as the sum of the prediction time tp and TTCpre_i.

sec.title: Multi-collision detection
sec.p: Two or more objects can collide with the ego vehicle simultaneously. This situation is illustrated in Figure 4. Several objects that have similar TTCs can be considered as one object with a sum of frontal overlaps. TTCth is a threshold parameter whose size depends on the relative velocity, and

caption.p: The FO of multi-collision detection.
TTC: time to collision.

sec.title: Simulation and experimental results
sec.p: In this section, the path prediction method is verified using experimental data and the collision detection results are shown from simulation and experimental data.

sec.title: Experimental verification of the path prediction
sec.p: Experiments are carried out to verify the performance of the path prediction method. The test vehicle is equipped with an RT-3000 sensor. The RT-3000 sensor manufactured by Oxford Technical Solutions can measure a local position X, Y from a reference frame with a differential Global Positioning System and the longitudinal and lateral accelerations of the test vehicle respectively. The yaw rate and the vehicle’s velocity are obtained from the vehicle’s controller area network (CAN).

The test scenarios are emergency braking and double lane change. Figure 5 shows the vehicle states of an emergency braking scenario. The vehicle drives at a constant velocity of 80 km/h and then the driver attempts emergency braking at 26 s. Figures 6 and 7 show the local X and Y position errors respectively between the measured and the predicted trajectories with a 0.5 s prediction time, The predicted path in the longitudinal direction shows a good performance (maximum error of less than 1 m) even for the emergency braking (deceleration of 1 g). This error can be caused by the vehicle’s velocity data from the CAN bus, which are less than the actual speed during high wheel-slip motions.

caption.p: The experimental tests on the emergency braking scenario.
X-position error between the measured and the predicted trajectories.
Y-position error between the measured and the predicted trajectories.

sec.p: Figure 8 shows the vehicle states of the double-lane-change scenario. The vehicle accelerates to a constant velocity of 80 km/h and then the driver performs a double lane change at 27 s. Figures 9 and 10 show the position errors between the measured and the predicted trajectories with a 0.3 s prediction time. The prediction results show that the X-position error is negligible and that the Y-position error is almost zero during the entire period except for the hard cornering from 27 s to 33 s. During the hard cornering (ay = 0.6 g), the maximum Y-position error is about 0.2 m, which is 5.5% of the lateral movement distance (3.6 m) during the lane change. The accuracy of the path prediction method is believed to be sufficiently good to be used for detecting a collision.

caption.p: The experimental tests on the double-lane-change scenario.
X-position error between the measured and the predicted trajectories.
Y-position error between the measured and the predicted trajectories.

sec.p: The prediction error can increase as the prediction time becomes longer if the acceleration and the yaw rate of the ego vehicle are not constant, or if the speed of the object is not constant. As long as the corresponding assumptions are met, the proposed method is believed to be very accurate in predicting the path and very useful for judging the impact conditions of a collision. It should be noted that the relative velocity and position data of the laser scanner are updated at every sampling time (e.g. 80 ms) and that the predicted path is also updated at every sampling time. Also, for a short prediction period such as 500 ms, the proposed method can effectively predict the path regardless of the manoeuvring conditions of the ego vehicle and objects.

sec.title: Simulation of the collision detection
sec.p: The collision detection simulation is carried out using the commercial vehicle simulation software PreScan, where the proposed path prediction as well as the TTC and the FO algorithms are implemented.17 A laser scanning sensor can be included using PreScan. The procedure of the proposed algorithm uses the PreScan graphics in Figure 11(a), which shows the contour points obtained from the scanning laser data and the predicted position of the object calculated from the path prediction method. Figure 11(b) shows the PreScan animation environment.

caption.p: (a) The graphical result from PreScan; (b) the PreScan animation view.

sec.p: Figures 12 and 13 show the results of comparing the proposed TTC and FO with the conventional TTC and FO for collision avoidance and for a collison respectively. The value of 1 for the FO represents 100% overlap.

caption.p: TTC and FO with collision avoidance.
TTC: time to collision; FO: frontal overlap.
TTC and FO with collision.
TTC: time to collision; FO: frontal overlap.

sec.p: Figure 12 shows the TTC and FO results when a collision is avoided without a crash. In this scenario, the ego vehicle is braking to avoid a collision with the front vehicle, and then the driver steers to avoid a crash at 0.8 s. The proposed method shows quite different results for the TTC and the FO from those of the conventional method. The proposed algorithm shows a zero FO value before steering starts at 0.8 s because only the region of interest is considered within the rectangle defined by lp_ego and drel. After 0.8 s, the FO value of the proposed algorithm becomes zero again much more quickly than with the conventional algorithm because of the predicted path in steering.

Figure 13 shows the results of a collision situation where the driver steers into the object. In this simulation scenario, the ego vehicle drives with no object in front and, suddenly, the driver steers and crashes into the object at 0.7 s. The conventional TTC and FO algorithms are based on the laser scanner data only without considering the path prediction. The conventional method detects the collision much later than the proposed method does and, thus, pre-crash systems cannot be activated effectively with the conventional method. However, the proposed TTC algorithm calculates the collision time accurately. The results demonstrate that the proposed TTC and FO algorithms are more accurate than the conventional method mainly owing to the introduction of the path prediction.

sec.title: Experimental test of the collision detection
sec.p: Figure 14 shows the test vehicle environment where analogue switches are used to measure the collision time and the Ibeo Lux® developed by Ibeo Automotive Systems GmbH is the equipment used for scanning the front. It has four layers with a horizontal field of view of 100°. The stopped balloon car is used for a frontal crash. Figures 15 and 16 show the experimental results obtained from the Ibeo Lux® data for constant vehicle velocities of 25 km/h and 45 km/h respectively. The true FO values in these cases are 100% and about 70% respectively at collision. The Y and X coordinates of these graphs represent the lateral offset and the longitudinal position respectively. The origin in these graphs represents the frontal centre of the ego vehicle. Tables 1 and 2 list the collision detection results of the TTC and the FO in the two scenarios respectively. The tables show that the proposed collision detection system provides an accurate TTC so that precrash systems can be activated effectively.

caption.p: Experimental test environments.
The experimental test result at a constant velocity of 25 km/h.
The experimental test result at a constant velocity of 45 km/h.
The experimental test results at a constant velocity of 25 km/h.
The experimental test results at a constant velocity of 45 km/h.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In order to determine the TTC and the FO between the ego vehicle and the object reliably, a path prediction method for object contour points is introduced in this study using the sensor data and vehicle’s motion data. Modified TTC and FO algorithms are proposed not only by considering the relative distance and velocity from the laser scanner, but also by including the path prediction method. The path prediction method is validated through experiments first. For a short prediction period such as 500 ms, the proposed method can effectively predict the collision environment regardless of the manoeuvring conditions of the ego vehicle and objects. The accuracies of the proposed TTC and FO algorithms are evaluated in simulations and collision experiments. Compared with the conventional TTC and FO, it is demonstrated that the proposed TTC and FO can predict the impact conditions more rapidly and more accurately in various manoeuvring cases.
